Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Testing the Existence of Magma Mush Zones and Potential Processes of Magma Differentiation in the Mid-crust with In situ Mineral Geochemistry
Award.AbstractNarration:
Detailed knowledge of magma plumbing systems beneath continent-margin volcanoes is crucial for understanding the evolution and growth of continental crust and the associated effects on crustal deformation and ore deposit formation. Understanding the time and length scales of processes in the magma plumbing system sheds light on the spatial distribution, type and frequency of volcanic eruptions and associated hazards. Although our understanding of continent-margin magmatism at depth is vastly improving, debate continues as to the dimensions, and even existence, of large magma volumes in sub-volcanic magma reservoirs, the interconnectivity between magma bodies through the thickness of the continental crust, and the importance and extent of processes that modify the chemistry of such magmas. The aim of this study is to investigate these missing, but critical pieces of the puzzle through study of plutons - ancient magmatic rocks formed at depth - as exposed in Yosemite National Park, California. Traditional bulk-rock element and isotope analyses have left too many fundamental questions about the architecture of crustal magmatic systems, resolution of which is a goal of this study through a new approach of utilizing micro-scale geochemical analysis of individual crystals in plutons. This research will also provide better data for numerical modeling efforts and has great potential to guide future studies of plutonic rocks.

This study will use texturally-constrained, element and isotope geochemical analysis of compositionally heterogeneous rock-forming and accessory minerals from strategically selected sites of the Tuolumne Intrusive Complex ? which was once a composite, mid-crustal arc magma reservoir - to test the following hypotheses. (1) Mineral zoning and inclusion relationships in plutonic rocks record distinct, decipherable magmatic histories. (2) Interconnected magma mush zones exist in mid-crustal reservoirs. (3) Mixing of crystal-rich magmas occurs between magmas injected from deeper levels and coexisting mush zones. (4) Crystal-liquid separation is an important process in the middle crust; consequently, many plutonic rocks are cumulate and do not represent liquid compositions. Testing these hypotheses will allow assessment of two models for mid-crustal arc plutons. A dike model predicts that magmas attain their chemical signatures in deep-crustal ?hot zones? and rise rapidly to sub-volcanic reservoirs without producing large magma bodies. A magma mush column model predicts that magmas form vertically-extensive reservoirs and undergo compositional modification at many crustal levels. Mineral analysis will allow identification of distinct mineral populations, interpretation of prevalent magmatic processes, assessment of the presence or absence of coeval magmas and their dimensions, and the ability of such magmas to chemically ?communicate?.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Granitic rocks characterize ancient zones of convergence of tectonic plates. As such, the mineral and chemical compositions and evolution of granitic magmas are widely used to interpret the thermal and structural history of plate margins. However, unlike compositionally-similar volcanic rocks (rhyolite), which provide an instantaneous snapshot of magmatic activity, plutons preserve an integrated record in terms of time, temperature, and chemical evolution. Nevertheless, in deeply-eroded plate-margin mountain belts, only granitic rocks are preserved. 

In order to extract quasi-temporal information about magmatic evolution, we undertook detailed analysis of mineral compositions, specifically analyzing the changes in compositions from the interior of crystals to their rims. Our focus was on the minerals hornblende, titanite, and apatite along with collaborative studies of plagioclase and K-feldspar with colleagues at California State University-Fullerton. All samples were from the Tuolumne Intrusive Complex, which underlies much of Yosemite National Park. The analyses involved imaging from outcrop to micron scale, followed by chemical analysis using electron microprobe and laser-ablation inductively-coupled plasma spectrometry. 

At the time of this writing, the results indicate the following:

--plagioclase was generally the first (highest temperature) mineral to crystallize and thus records the greatest amount of chemical information.

--hornblende crystallized at temperatures near 850°C and variably records simple crystallization or episodic crystallization form a magma with repeated inputs of more primitive, hotter liquids. 

--titanite crystallized after hornblende, most probably after the magma had reached an immobile or weakly mobile 'mush' stage. 

--apatite crystallization varied among different rock units. In older, higher temperature magmas it appeared just before hornblende crystallization but in younger, cooler magmas it appears synchronously with plagioclase.

--comparison of rock compositions to calculate parental melt composition indicates that most rocks in the complex are cumulates. That is, the magma lost some of the liquid component prior to final solidification. This conclusion is supported by on-going studies involving the mineral zircon, and the conditions necessary for zircon to crystallize.

--through the use of calculated melt compositions and analyzed feldspar compositions, it is possible to estimate the H2O content of the magmas. This value was in the relatively narrow range of 4 to 5% by weight.

Post-award research is continuing, with the specific goal of integrating the various data sets into a single evolutionary record of Tuolumne magmas. The results of data integration will then be published for both technical and general audiences.

In addition to presenting results to a general audience, other broader outcomes of our research include support for an MS and a Ph.D. student, as well as undergraduate student assistants. These students were able to gain valuable experience in the field and the laboratory, and to interact at high technical levels with faculty and student colleagues at Fullerton and the University of Southern California. Moreover, they gained experience with cutting-edge analytical methods which are now being used in many fields in addition to geology/geochemistry.

This final note on technology is important. The integration of analysis from field scale to micron scale is, in this writer's opinion, the route forward in the study of granitic rocks. It provides a means by which the integrated record provided by the bulk rock may be unraveled into individual threads of information which are then read, much like a tape recording, to detail the crystallization history of the magma.
